pull.title: doc: document json rpc endpoints
pull.body:
fixes #20246

This documents the two JSON-RPC endpoints available, details when they are active, specifies when they can or must be used, and outlines some known behaviour quirks.

events.body:
<!--e57a25ab6845829454e8d69fc972939a-->

The following sections might be updated with supplementary metadata relevant to reviewers and maintainers.

<!--021abf342d371248e50ceaed478a90ca-->
### Reviews
See [the guideline](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#code-review) for information on the review process.
| Type | Reviewers |
| ---- | --------- |
| ACK | [fanquake](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/27225#pullrequestreview-1457807717) |
| Concept ACK | [pinheadmz](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/27225#pullrequestreview-1330876223), [kristapsk](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/27225#issuecomment-1460632028) |

If your review is incorrectly listed, please react with 👎 to this comment and the bot will ignore it on the next update.
Nit - there is typo in commit message / PR title (s/docment/document/).

verification.payload:
tree 1f042516335b08918130ed5a4f47b8a2a8f7d2d4
parent d4ebdceaef130e4b68e5d5db67eecfefd24b4239
author willcl-ark <will@256k1.dev> 1678229603 +0000
committer willcl-ark <will@256k1.dev> 1678351319 +0000

doc: document json rpc endpoints

fixes #20246

Document both JSON-RPC endpoints, when they are active and which types
of requests they are able to service.

Adds two example curl requests, one for each endpoint.

events.message:
doc: document json rpc endpoints

fixes #20246

Document both JSON-RPC endpoints, when they are active and which types
of requests they are able to service.

Adds two example curl requests, one for each endpoint.

events.body:
> Nit - there is typo in commit message / PR title (s/docment/document/).

Thanks, i've updated this in 65e3abcbf

> > Nit - there is typo in commit message / PR title (s/docment/document/).
> 
> Thanks, i've updated this in 65e3abcbf

You should also edit PR title. It is used by [github-merge.py](https://github.com/bitcoin-core/bitcoin-maintainer-tools/blob/main/github-merge.py).

> 

Thanks, I thought that updated from the force push, but apparently not. Now also done :)
ACK 65e3abcbf2b9e818f3b9f1ba35f3cfe7df5e3811 - Seems fine. Can be improved if need be.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -5,6 +5,36 @@ The headless daemon `bitcoind` has the JSON-RPC API enabled by default, the GUI
 option. In the GUI it is possible to execute RPC methods in the Debug Console
 Dialog.
 
+## Endpoints
+
+There are two JSON-RPC endpoints on the server:
+
+1. `/`
+2. `/wallet/<walletname>/`
comments.body:
A few ideas about these:
- could include full path `http://localhost:{port}/`
- could list relevant ports per network (i.e. main=8332, regtest=18443 etc)
- not sure if this applies here but I'm used to seeing API endpoints with variables expressed like `/wallet/:walletname`, at least for REST APIs. I dunno if there is otherwise a convention for that

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -5,6 +5,36 @@ The headless daemon `bitcoind` has the JSON-RPC API enabled by default, the GUI
 option. In the GUI it is possible to execute RPC methods in the Debug Console
 Dialog.
 
+## Endpoints
+
+There are two JSON-RPC endpoints on the server:
+
+1. `/`
+2. `/wallet/<walletname>/`
+
+### `/` endpoint
+
+This endpoint is always active and can service both wallet and non-wallet
+requests when there are zero or one wallets loaded.
comments.body:
```suggestion
This endpoint is always active for non-wallet requests, and can service wallet requests when exactly one wallet is loaded.
```

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -5,6 +5,36 @@ The headless daemon `bitcoind` has the JSON-RPC API enabled by default, the GUI
 option. In the GUI it is possible to execute RPC methods in the Debug Console
 Dialog.
 
+## Endpoints
+
+There are two JSON-RPC endpoints on the server:
+
+1. `/`
+2. `/wallet/<walletname>/`
+
+### `/` endpoint
+
+This endpoint is always active and can service both wallet and non-wallet
+requests when there are zero or one wallets loaded.
+
+### `/wallet/<walletname>/` endpoint
+
+This endpoint is only activated when the wallet component has been compiled in
comments.body: It is also always active for non-wallet requests before any wallets are loaded.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -5,6 +5,36 @@ The headless daemon `bitcoind` has the JSON-RPC API enabled by default, the GUI
 option. In the GUI it is possible to execute RPC methods in the Debug Console
 Dialog.
 
+## Endpoints
+
+There are two JSON-RPC endpoints on the server:
+
+1. `/`
+2. `/wallet/<walletname>/`
+
+### `/` endpoint
+
+This endpoint is always active and can service both wallet and non-wallet
+requests when there are zero or one wallets loaded.
+
+### `/wallet/<walletname>/` endpoint
+
+This endpoint is only activated when the wallet component has been compiled in
+and can service both wallet and non-wallet requests. It MUST be used for wallet
+requests when two or more wallets are loaded.
+
+This endpoint is equivalent to using bitcoin-cli with the `-rpcwallet=` parameter.
comments.body:
```suggestion
This is the endpoint used by bitcoin-cli when a `-rpcwallet=` parameter is passed in.
```

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -5,6 +5,36 @@ The headless daemon `bitcoind` has the JSON-RPC API enabled by default, the GUI
 option. In the GUI it is possible to execute RPC methods in the Debug Console
 Dialog.
 
+## Endpoints
+
+There are two JSON-RPC endpoints on the server:
+
+1. `/`
+2. `/wallet/<walletname>/`
+
+### `/` endpoint
+
+This endpoint is always active and can service both wallet and non-wallet
+requests when there are zero or one wallets loaded.
+
+### `/wallet/<walletname>/` endpoint
+
+This endpoint is only activated when the wallet component has been compiled in
+and can service both wallet and non-wallet requests. It MUST be used for wallet
+requests when two or more wallets are loaded.
+
+This endpoint is equivalent to using bitcoin-cli with the `-rpcwallet=` parameter.
+
+Best practice would dictate using the `/wallet/<walletname>/` endpoint for ALL
+requests when multiple wallets are in use.
comments.body:
actually seems like its the right endpoint to use for all requests all the time! For non wallet requests you can still use `/wallet` with no wallet name

```
$ curl http://u:p@localhost:18443/wallet/ --data '{"method":"getblockcount"}'
{"result":206,"error":null,"id":null}
```

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -5,6 +5,36 @@ The headless daemon `bitcoind` has the JSON-RPC API enabled by default, the GUI
 option. In the GUI it is possible to execute RPC methods in the Debug Console
 Dialog.
 
+## Endpoints
+
+There are two JSON-RPC endpoints on the server:
+
+1. `/`
+2. `/wallet/<walletname>/`
+
+### `/` endpoint
+
+This endpoint is always active and can service both wallet and non-wallet
+requests when there are zero or one wallets loaded.
+
+### `/wallet/<walletname>/` endpoint
+
+This endpoint is only activated when the wallet component has been compiled in
+and can service both wallet and non-wallet requests. It MUST be used for wallet
+requests when two or more wallets are loaded.
+
+This endpoint is equivalent to using bitcoin-cli with the `-rpcwallet=` parameter.
+
+Best practice would dictate using the `/wallet/<walletname>/` endpoint for ALL
+requests when multiple wallets are in use.
+
+### Quirks:
+
+* With more than one wallet loaded the `/` endpoint will still be able to
+service non-wallet requests.
+* When active the `/wallet/<walletname>/` endpoint can still be used when no
+wallet is loaded by providing a dummy `walletname`.
comments.body:
I think these can be folded in above if you like my suggestions.

I think a few `curl` examples might be appropriate here as well since this document is covering raw endpoint stuff

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -5,6 +5,36 @@ The headless daemon `bitcoind` has the JSON-RPC API enabled by default, the GUI
 option. In the GUI it is possible to execute RPC methods in the Debug Console
 Dialog.
 
+## Endpoints

+1. `/`
+2. `/wallet/<walletname>/`
+
+### `/` endpoint
+
+This endpoint is always active and can service both wallet and non-wallet
+requests when there are zero or one wallets loaded.
comments.body:
I see your point here, but I was also trying to distinguish: active=enabled, services=wallet/non-wallet.

How about:

> This endpoint is always active. It can always service non-wallet requests and can service wallet requests when exactly one wallet is loaded.

@@ -5,6 +5,36 @@ The headless daemon `bitcoind` has the JSON-RPC API enabled by default, the GUI

 Dialog.

comments.body:
Oh, I didn't know you could use the endpoint without a wallet name at all!

IMO it makes sense to specify that it should be used with the `wallet/<walletname>/` syntax for multiwallet (as designed?)

comments.body: yeah i dunno whats best to reccomend. I think personally Id use `/` for node requests and `/wallet/walletname` for any wallet request no matter how many wallets are loaded.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -5,6 +5,36 @@ The headless daemon `bitcoind` has the JSON-RPC API enabled by default, the GUI
 option. In the GUI it is possible to execute RPC methods in the Debug Console
 Dialog.
 
+## Endpoints
+
+There are two JSON-RPC endpoints on the server:
+
+1. `/`
+2. `/wallet/<walletname>/`
comments.body:
Personally I feel it's clearer just to use the endpoints themselves, rather than cluttering with hosts and ports.

Also, we have examples now!

@@ -5,6 +5,36 @@ The headless daemon `bitcoind` has the JSON-RPC API enabled by default, the GUI
 option. In the GUI it is possible to execute RPC methods in the Debug Console
 Dialog.
 
+## Endpoints
+
+There are two JSON-RPC endpoints on the server:
+

+

+

+

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -5,6 +5,41 @@ The headless daemon `bitcoind` has the JSON-RPC API enabled by default, the GUI
 option. In the GUI it is possible to execute RPC methods in the Debug Console
 Dialog.
 
+## Endpoints
+
+There are two JSON-RPC endpoints on the server:
+
+1. `/`
+2. `/wallet/<walletname>/`
+
+### `/` endpoint
+
+This endpoint is always active.
+It can always service non-wallet requests and can service wallet requests when
+exactly one wallet is loaded.
+
+### `/wallet/<walletname>/` endpoint
+
+This endpoint is only activated when the wallet component has been compiled in.
+It can service both wallet and non-wallet requests.
+It MUST be used for wallet requests when two or more wallets are loaded.
+
+This is the endpoint used by bitcoin-cli when a `-rpcwallet=` parameter is passed in.
+
+Best practice would dictate using the `/wallet/<walletname>/` endpoint for ALL
+requests when multiple wallets are in use.
+
+### Examples
+
+```sh
+# Get block count from the / endpoint when rpcuser=alice and rpcport=38332
+$ curl --user alice --data-binary '{"jsonrpc": "1.0", "id": "0", "method": "getblockcount", "params": []}' -H 'content-type: text/plain;' localhost:38332/
+
+# Get balance from the /wallet/walletname endpoint when rpcuser=alice, rpcport=38332 and rpcwallet=desc-wallet
+$ curl --user alice --data-binary '{"jsonrpc": "1.0", "id": "0", "method": "getbalance", "params": []}' -H 'content-type: text/plain;' localhost:38332/wallet/desc-wallet
comments.body:
If this gets merged before #27101, remind me to update to `2.0` ;-)

Technically I think `jsonrpc:"1.0"` isn't necessary and doesn't actually do anything.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -5,6 +5,41 @@ The headless daemon `bitcoind` has the JSON-RPC API enabled by default, the GUI
 option. In the GUI it is possible to execute RPC methods in the Debug Console
 Dialog.
 
+## Endpoints
+
+There are two JSON-RPC endpoints on the server:
+
+1. `/`
+2. `/wallet/<walletname>/`
+
+### `/` endpoint
+
+This endpoint is always active.
+It can always service non-wallet requests and can service wallet requests when
+exactly one wallet is loaded.
+
+### `/wallet/<walletname>/` endpoint
+
+This endpoint is only activated when the wallet component has been compiled in.
+It can service both wallet and non-wallet requests.
+It MUST be used for wallet requests when two or more wallets are loaded.
+
+This is the endpoint used by bitcoin-cli when a `-rpcwallet=` parameter is passed in.
+
+Best practice would dictate using the `/wallet/<walletname>/` endpoint for ALL
+requests when multiple wallets are in use.
+
+### Examples
+
+```sh
+# Get block count from the / endpoint when rpcuser=alice and rpcport=38332
+$ curl --user alice --data-binary '{"jsonrpc": "1.0", "id": "0", "method": "getblockcount", "params": []}' -H 'content-type: text/plain;' localhost:38332/
+
+# Get balance from the /wallet/walletname endpoint when rpcuser=alice, rpcport=38332 and rpcwallet=desc-wallet
+$ curl --user alice --data-binary '{"jsonrpc": "1.0", "id": "0", "method": "getbalance", "params": []}' -H 'content-type: text/plain;' localhost:38332/wallet/desc-wallet
comments.body: Why are the examples using signet port? I think we should use mainnet port (8332) same as all the [RPC examples](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/23e2bfcbc42849daa8e2b69f9bbdc526bc8743a7/src/rpc/util.cpp#L160).

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -5,6 +5,41 @@ The headless daemon `bitcoind` has the JSON-RPC API enabled by default, the GUI
 option. In the GUI it is possible to execute RPC methods in the Debug Console
 Dialog.
 
+## Endpoints
+
+There are two JSON-RPC endpoints on the server:
+
+1. `/`
+2. `/wallet/<walletname>/`
+
+### `/` endpoint
+
+This endpoint is always active.
+It can always service non-wallet requests and can service wallet requests when
+exactly one wallet is loaded.
+
+### `/wallet/<walletname>/` endpoint
+
+This endpoint is only activated when the wallet component has been compiled in.
+It can service both wallet and non-wallet requests.
+It MUST be used for wallet requests when two or more wallets are loaded.
+
+This is the endpoint used by bitcoin-cli when a `-rpcwallet=` parameter is passed in.
+
+Best practice would dictate using the `/wallet/<walletname>/` endpoint for ALL
+requests when multiple wallets are in use.
+
+### Examples
+
+```sh
+# Get block count from the / endpoint when rpcuser=alice and rpcport=38332
+$ curl --user alice --data-binary '{"jsonrpc": "1.0", "id": "0", "method": "getblockcount", "params": []}' -H 'content-type: text/plain;' localhost:38332/
+
+# Get balance from the /wallet/walletname endpoint when rpcuser=alice, rpcport=38332 and rpcwallet=desc-wallet
+$ curl --user alice --data-binary '{"jsonrpc": "1.0", "id": "0", "method": "getbalance", "params": []}' -H 'content-type: text/plain;' localhost:38332/wallet/desc-wallet
comments.body: I'm happy to be persuaded either way here, no particular reason for using signet (other than I was using it for testing). Although I personally don't think it matters much as the comment for each shows which variables are being used
